Hi @Weslei_WesleiRibeiro 

Passos Recomendados para Solucionar

Verifique o Material no Cadastro:

Use a transação MM03 para buscar o material PACAIN/XTST.

Confirme se o material existe e se possui a visão Planta para a planta 0045.

Se não existir, crie-o usando a transação MM01 e informe as visões e dados necessários.

Verifique a Mapeamento de Integração:

Se essa for uma integração com outro sistema (por exemplo, PACAIN), verifique as tabelas de mapeamento ou configurações de customização.

Garanta que o material esteja corretamente mapeado entre os sistemas.

Faça ajustes, se necessário, no sistema de origem ou nas regras de mapeamento do middleware.

Reprocessar o Documento:

Após corrigir os dados mestre ou o mapeamento, reprocese o documento.

Use a transação de monitoramento ou a transação SMQ2 para gerenciar a fila de entrada e tentar o reprocessamento.

 

Espero que isso ajude.

Atenciosamente.

Chris

entry.title: How to store long Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers in SAP S/4HANA ERP Products
entry.content:
How Official Document Numbers (ODN) Framework can help customers to store long Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA

 

 

In my last Blogposts I introduced you into How Official Document Numbering helps to fulfil the Polish KSeF Requirements in S4HANA Public Cloud and also informed you about How you can manage Polish KSeF Requirement in SAP ... - SAP Community

 

With this new Blog I´d like to give you an example of how the new ODN Framework can help you to store Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers, larger than 16 digits, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA.

 

In the following example we will focus on Poland as country, as this is a common scenario there. But the new ODN Framework is not restricted to any country and can be used everywhere.

 

 

Configuration

1.  Maintain Official Document Number Types - Transaction: “ODNTYP”

 

Create the ODN Types (Examples):

  • ZLINV - Long Invoice Number

 

 

 

 

2.  Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type
- Transaction: “ODNINTTYP”

 

Map your custom official document number type to the SAP-delivered internal official document number type so that the system can correctly derive the official document number within your consuming application.

Procedure

  • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type activity.
  • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
  • Choose New Entries.
  • In the ODN Internal Type field, choose the SAP-delivered internal official document number type LIRN.
  • In the ODN Type field, choose your custom official document number type; for example, LINV.
  • Save your changes.

 

 

3.  Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics TA: “ODNTYPC”

 

Set the properties of your custom official document number type, such as its length and how it is processed.

 

Procedure

    • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics activity.
    • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
    • In the Assign Official Document Number Types to Country step, choose New Entries and add your custom official document number types from above.
    • Choose the new entry you have added for your custom official document number type and then go to User Interface Settings.
    • In the ODN Length field, enter the length you need, for example 200 digits.
    • Go to Process Specific Settings.
    • Choose New Entries and add the following entry:

 

  • For ZLINV:

 

 

 

  • For MM_SUPPLIER_INV:

 

 

4.  Example – Supplier Invoice via transaction MIRO

 

  • Enter the invoice relevant data and then press “Additional Fiscal Data”

 

 

  • Now Enter the Official Document Numbers relevant for your business in Poland (KSeF and Long Invoice Number, if needed):

 

 

Data Access via CDS Views:

Process

CDS View

SD Billing

I_BillingDocumentODN

FI Customer/Supplier invoice

I_AccountingDocumentODN

MM Supplier Invoice

I_SupplierInvoiceODN

 

 

 

The Business Processes and SAP Help Documentation for our example in Poland can be found here:

Business Area

Supported Business Processes

Description

Sourcing and Procurement

Configuring Long Invoice Number (PLLIN) for Supplier Invoices

You can manually maintain the official document number in supplier invoices. The system validates this value based on the properties maintained in the configuration.

 

 

Availability

The solution shown above is available for:

  • SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Public Edition (current Release)
  • SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA Versions 1709 – 2025.

 

Regarding SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA, there are two ways of consuming the solution.

  1. You can install the next feature Package for your S/4HANA Solution
  2. You can install the notes which have been released recently:
  • In this case refer to the note collection in SAP Note 3565339 for additional details and also note 3639622 - ODN Internal Type - LIRN

 

 

I hope that I was able to provide you a good overview about how use the new ODN Framework could support you to store long invoice references.

 

Thanks,

 

See you next time!

 

Christian Seelinger

entry.title: Re: OData Service — Data Retrieved in Debug, but HTTP 500...
entry.content:
Hi @ashokkandel 

In reference to the comment made earlier, the HTTP 500 error you see after pressing F8 to finish the request, despite correct data in debug, usually points to an issue occurring during the OData serialization or response handling phase.

There are a few common causes and these include the following:

Data type mismatch in metadata or runtime data. Even small discrepancies between your MPC metadata definitions and the actual runtime data can cause failures during response serialization.

Null or unexpected values. If any field in your response data is null or contains unexpected values e.g., empty strings for numeric fields the OData framework might raise internal errors.

Large payload or buffering issues. Very large datasets or inefficient buffering could cause memory exceptions leading to HTTP 500 errors.

Incorrect method implementation. It is important to note that sometimes, not properly handling deep structure fields or associations in GET_ENTITYSET or GET_ENTITY can cause runtime errors.

Backend system parameters. Parameters related to runtime memory and shared objects size e.g., abap or shared_objects_size_MB may be too low, which may cause internal issues when the service tries to serialize and deliver the data.

 

I would recommend that you:

First, check your /IWFND/ERROR_LOG as recommended by SAP Note 1797736 to get detailed error information.

Validate that your MPC metadata exactly matches your underlying DDIC structure and that no incompatible types or missing fields exist.

Ensure you add runtime null checks and default values in your GET_ENTITY and GET_ENTITYSET method implementations.

Reduce the size of the dataset returned for initial testing by limiting filter conditions and Increase runtime memory parameters if needed.

Test your OData service calls via external clients like Postman to confirm if the issue is related to UI/browser specifics.

The summary is that this error is fairly common when metadata and runtime data are out-of-sync or when encountering unexpected data during serialization.

Hope this helps.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BTP Cloud Foundry Consumed by all spaces exceeds any...
entry.content:
Hi @CDN_Steve 

This memory discrepancy likely points to one or more of the following causes:


It is important to note that sometimes, apps or service instances that are no longer active remain allocated memory without being visible in the current space stats. These can consume memory reserved by your org quota.


Memory may be reserved or consumed by other spaces in the org that are not visible in your current space view, or by the org-level quota that includes reserved buffers.


Beyond user apps, Cloud Foundry runtime and platform components may reserve memory quota counted against the org quota but not attributed to individual spaces or apps.


It is possible that the memory usage figures are stale or inconsistent due to cloud platform glitches; previously reported issues may clear themselves over time but require investigation by SAP support.

I would recommend you consider doing the following:

List all spaces and apps across the org. Use CLI commands for example cf spaces, cf apps –all or cloud platform console to verify if any other spaces or apps are consuming memory unexpectedly.

Check service instances:
Confirm if any bound service instances consume memory quota.

Review quota assignments. Ensure to verify the quota plans assigned at org and space levels and any reserved buffers.

Restart or scale down unused apps. Please note, if orphaned apps exist, stop or delete them to release memory.

If the issue still exists, provide logs and memory usage snapshots to SAP support for deeper platform investigation.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Outbound IP Ranges
entry.content:
Hi @dogukanpadel 

To obtain the egress IP address ranges for your SAP Public Cloud instance needed for bank integration user and IP mapping, here is the recommended approach:

SAP Public Cloud which includes Cloud Foundry egress IPs are managed by the underlying cloud infrastructure and IPs can change over time. Examples are the Hyperscalers.

SAP provides region-specific IP ranges for some services and environments via official documentation and GitHub projects, for example:

SAP BTP Kyma Runtime egress IP utility scripts to discover live egress IPs.

SAP Help Portal pages listing SAP HANA Cloud and Integration Suite IPs.

For your specific SAP Public Cloud tenant, you can check SAP Service Interfaces and Network documentation specific for your region.

You also have the option to contact SAP Cloud Operations or your SAP Account team to request the official IP ranges assigned to your tenant or landscape. Keep in mind these IPs may change with platform updates, so ongoing communication or subscription to SAP notices is advisable.

If you have Kubernetes or Cloud Foundry access within your SAP environment, you can also run scripts or tools that query live egress IP addresses to capture current outbound IPs used by your applications.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Planned Inventory active in LS03N, how to clear yello...
entry.content:
The yellow triangle indicates that planned inventory is still active for the bin.

Even if all inventory records are cleared, the system may still show the bin as blocked for inventory due to:

  • Incomplete clearing of inventory documents
  • Residual entries in tables like LAGP or LINP
  • System inconsistencies after manual or partial clearing

Go to LX22, tick the boxes Not counted or Partially counted bins so that, you may find an inventory document still linked to the bin even if LS03N shows it as cleared. Check table LAGP for the bin, field IVIVO (Inventory active indicator) may still be set. If IVIVO = X, the system considers the bin as planned for inventory. Check SAP note 824904 which provides a correction report and it updates internal fields and clears the yellow triangle. But as cautioned in the note, you should be very careful before running the report. Also, check for SAP note 2124215 which gives two resolutions.

entry.title: Re: Adaptation Project - Select application - Blank
entry.content:
HI @krish96 

The reason can related to various areas. A few of them are:

It can refer to system or tooling limitations. Some apps cannot currently be configured or extended via Adaptation Projects in Business Application Studio and require SAP Web IDE instead.

It can also be missing required SAP UI5 versions or platform components. The apps must meet minimum UI5 version requirements which is usually 1.56 or higher and run on supported SAP front-end framework versions.

The Workspace or project context can also be a trigger. Note that the Adaptation Project wizard only shows applications available in the current workspace that meet specific criteria.

Permissions or authorizations issues that can also prevent the loading of applications.

There are some known UI or feature restrictions. Some new features in BAS may cause empty application lists, requiring updates or workarounds such as regenerating the entire project or adjusting config files.

However, you can try solving that by:

Verifying the app you want to adapt is compatible with Adaptation Projects. This can be Fiori elements Object Page or List Page.

Ensuring your environment supports the UI5 version and system components.

You can try using SAP Web IDE if your app is not visible in BAS Adaptation Projects.

Checking your workspace and system authorizations.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: VAT number doesn't print on invoice
entry.content:
Some root causes are

  • SAP often uses country-dependent logic in the invoice form templates (SmartForms, Adobe Forms, or Output Management). Some countries (e.g., EU members) require VAT numbers on invoices by law, so the template includes them. For countries like Japan, Indonesia, UAE, the template may omit VAT numbers unless explicitly configured.
  • The Customer Master Record (BP) may not have the Tax Number 1 or VAT Registration Number maintained for these countries. If the field is blank or not mapped correctly, it won’t print.
  • SAP’s localization content may control whether VAT numbers are considered relevant for invoice output in certain countries. For example, Japan uses a different tax ID format (Corporate Number), and UAE uses TRN (Tax Registration Number).

So please check the below areas:

Go to BP transaction or Manage Business Partner Master Data app. Check if Tax Number 1 or VAT Registration Number is maintained for customers in Japan, Indonesia, UAE. If not, update it manually or via data migration.

Identify the form used for invoice output (e.g., SD_BIL_INV or custom Adobe Form). Review the logic in the Data Provider Class or Form Interface. Modify the condition to include all relevant countries or remove country filtering entirely.

In Output Management, check if the form variant or template differs by country. Ensure the same form logic applies across all countries where VAT number is required.

SAP provides localized tax categories for Japan in the Business Partner master data like JP3 & JP4. Similarly, for UAE, SAP supports TRN as a localized tax field

entry.title: Re: Delivery Creation date VL10
entry.content:
VL10 transactions (like VL10B, VL10C, etc.) use delivery due date logic, which is based on delivery creation date ≤ planned delivery date. But here's the twist:

The Delivery Creation Date in VL10 is not a strict match filter. It’s a cutoff date.  SAP checks if the planned delivery date (from the schedule line) is less than or equal to this date.

  • When you use “equal to 15.08.2025”, SAP interprets this as “planned delivery date = 15.08.2025”, which may not match due to time stamps or internal rounding.
  • When you use “less than or equal to 15.08.2025”, SAP includes all items with planned delivery dates up to and including 15.08.2025 and this should work.
  • When you use “less than or equal to 14.08.2025”, the planned date is excluded.  So no items will be displayed.

Recommended approach is always use “less than or equal to” for the Delivery Creation Date in VL10. This ensures:

  • Items with planned delivery dates on or before the date are picked up.
  • You avoid issues with time stamps or internal scheduling buffers.

entry.title: Re: Supplier and Purchasing group email not picked in PO...
entry.content:
Even if the email addresses are correct, SAP might still fail if:

  • the sender email address is not mapped correctly in the Email Settings node.
  • The receiver email address is not being picked up due to missing or incorrect context mapping.
  • Go to Output Parameter Determination → Email Settings and verify Sender email is explicitly defined. Receiver email is mapped from the correct field (e.g., BusinessPartner.EmailAddress).
  • Check if the output type is configured to use EMAIL and not PRINT or XML by mistake.
  • SAP performs strict validation. Even small issues can trigger APOC_OR_MESSAGES105. Extra spaces before/after the email.
  • Hidden characters (especially if copy-pasted). Multiple addresses in one field without proper separators. It is better to use transaction BP or SU01 and manually retype the email address. Avoid copy-paste.


Finally, Run SLG1 with:

  • Object: APOC
  • Subobject: OR_MESSAGES
  • Date/time of the failed output

Check the full message context—it often includes the exact field or logic that failed.

Also try triggering the same output manually using Manage Output Items and see if the email is populated correctly. If it works manually but fails automatically, the issue is likely in the BRF+ determination logic.

entry.title: Re: Hyperlink formulas
entry.content:
Hi @Connor_Sullivan54 

Thank you for your question.

There are a few common causes to your error. It could be incorrectly formatted or inaccessible file path, the client viewing the report doesn’t have access to the network share or missing or incorrect escaping in the path string in your formula. Here are important points and steps to help you resolve that:

First, use the Format Field à Hyperlink tab to select your text or formula field, open Format Field, then go to Hyperlink.

For the hyperlink type, Choose "A File" if linking to a file path. Use the formula editor to insert your dynamic path like \\\\<myserver>\\Files\\_Customer_Files_New\\Municipality\\Projects\\Test.pdf.

Make sure to double backslash each folder separator (\\) so Crystal Reports interprets it correctly.

Then verify the file path works on the client machine opening the report (the PC must have network access to that server path).

Finally, you can format text with HTML links using <a href="">link text</a> in a formula field, then set Text Interpretation to "HTML Text" under Format → Paragraph tab if you want custom text instead of the raw URL.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Error SAP note 3605421
entry.content:
Not sure in which version you are working. Normally, this error typically occurs due to one of the following:

  • The correction instructions are in a format not supported by your current SAP_BASIS release or Support Package level.
  • The note may contain newer syntax or metadata that your system cannot parse.
  • There may be a missing prerequisite note or a program inconsistency in Note Assistant.

So check SAP_BASIS and your Support Package Level. Alternatively, you can check SAP Note 853524 which addresses SCWN409 errors and provides a fix for Note Assistant parsing issues.

entry.title: Re: Essential transfer parameters are missing in record: 000001 message posting a reservation
entry.content:
This error is usually triggered when mandatory fields for the movement type or reservation are missing or incomplete. Common causes include:

  • Missing plant, storage location, or movement type
  • Incomplete account assignment (e.g., cost center, order)
  • Reservation created via a work order or custom process that didn’t populate all required fields
  • Attempting to post a goods issue against a reservation without sufficient stock or proper reference

Check the below areas

entry.title: Re: MRP-generated purchase requisitions to have source de...
entry.content:
Hi @Haily 

To have your MRP-generated purchase requisitions automatically include source determination in S/4HANA Public Cloud, you should ensure the following:

Make sure to maintain valid sources of supply like Purchasing Info Records with automatic sourcing enabled, Source Lists marked as MRP relevant, Contracts and Quota Arrangements for the materials and plants involved. The system assigns sources based on priority among these master data objects during the MRP run.

Please note that properly maintained and active source data will enable MRP to assign sources automatically. Therefore, allowing purchase requisitions to be converted into purchase orders via scheduling.

If no valid source is found, manual assignment or adjustment of master data may be necessary.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: FG TO RM NORMS CONSUMPTION
entry.content:
Hello @gaudalvi 

Thank you for your question

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, you can report FG to RM consumption norms by using released CDS views for BOM data rather than accessing tables directly.

Recommended Approach

Start from the FG material

  • Use CDS view I_MaterialBOMHeader to identify the BOM header for the FG, including usage, plant, and validity.

Get BOM components

  • Use CDS view I_MaterialBOMItem to retrieve the RM or SFG components, along with base quantities.

Recursive explosion for SFGs

  • If any component is a Semi-Finished Good, repeat steps 1–2 until you list all leaf-level RMs.

Apply consumption norms logic

    • Incorporate unit of measure conversions and effective validity dates to ensure norms are accurate for the reporting period.

Develop Z-Report

    • Consume these CDS views in a custom RAP application or Analytical Query for reporting.

Check this SAP Documentation for your reference SAP Help – Bills of Material in S/4HANA Cloud

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Condition Contract - Delta Accrual
entry.content:
You can use Accrual Engine with Periodic Accrual Runs. SAP’s Accrual Engine (or Accruals Management in S/4HANA) allows you to:

  • define accrual objects linked to condition contracts
  • Schedule monthly accrual postings
  • Control posting logic independently of settlement

You can configure accruals to post fixed monthly amounts or percentage-based accruals based on contract value.

In the Accrual Object Type configuration, set Accrual Method to Periodic. This ensures each accrual run posts only for the current period, not cumulatively. This method is ideal for contracts with fixed monthly values or evenly distributed accruals.

While the settlement calendar drives settlement timing, you can decouple accrual logic by not referencing the calendar in your accrual object. Instead, use posting date or period-based triggers in the accrual run. This ensures accruals are posted monthly regardless of settlement frequency.

If you're in S/4HANA Public Cloud, use the Manage Accruals app to:

  • create accrual objects manually or via mass upload
  • Schedule monthly accrual runs
  • Monitor and reverse accruals as needed

With the above settings, while testing, you can validate by performing the below steps

  • Create a condition contract with multiple validity periods
  • Create an accrual object with periodic method
  • Run accruals monthly and check that each posting is standalone, not cumulative
  • Compare with settlement postings to confirm decoupling

entry.title: Re: How to confirm configuration point in Costing Variant...
entry.content:
Hello @wangxlbest 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the configuration for the Costing Variant and its control elements (Costing Type, Date Control, Quantity Structure Control, Transfer Control) is maintained directly within the Define Costing Variants activity in the CBC / Manage Your Solution environment. These elements do not have standalone SSCUI numbers.

For reference, the key related configuration points are:

  • Define Costing Variants – includes Costing Type, Date Control, Qty Structure Control, Transfer Control
  • Define Valuation Variants for Material Cost Estimates  SSCUI 102607
  • Define Valuation Variants per Plant
  • Define Cost Component Structure

You can find the official SAP documentation here
Define Costing Variants – SAP Help

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: The Convergence of Enterprise Data and Gen AI in Oil, Gas and Energy
entry.content:
The Oil, Gas, and Energy team has made tremendous progress this year in advancing relevant AI solutions that drive operational efficiency and business transformation. Our efforts are focused not only on delivering value through targeted projects but also on building robust partnerships to expand our capabilities in agentic AI solutions. We are excited to highlight major initiatives currently delivered and in development.

1. Where Is My Stuff
Holistic Visibility Through Natural Language AI

Purpose

The first version of "Where Is My Stuff" was released in Q2 2025, adding a natural-language skill to Joule. This feature allows users to request the latest information on non-stock items managed in the Field Logistics solution using simple English, providing real-time visibility across locations through intuitive queries.

Key Benefits:

  • Speeds up access to critical procurement data, ensuring teams get the information they need without delays and eliminates manual navigation through multiple Field Logistics screens; answers appear instantly via chat.
  • Productivity gains as field personnel spend less time searching for data and more time acting on it.

Potential Impacts:

  • Faster, better-informed procurement and logistics decisions, leading to fewer material shortages or over-orders.
  • Reduced operational costs through time savings and avoidance of manual errors.
  • Delivers faster responses that elevate customer satisfaction and loyalty.
  • Unlocks cost savings through leaner, more efficient processes.

2. Zero Touch PRA
Automating Gas Plant Statement Processing with AI

Purpose:
Zero Touch PRA, anticipated for release in Q1 2026, streamlines how analysts upload gas plant statements across Natural Gas Liquids (NGL) sales with minimal manual involvement.

Key Benefits:

  • Slashes hours of tedious manual data entry, freeing you to focus on high-impact work.
  • Drives faster, more reliable data processing, streamlining operations from input to insight.

Potential Impacts:

  • Accelerated critical data analysis, enabling quicker, more informed decision-making.
  • Minimizes costly errors by reducing reliance on manual input.
  • Sharpens reporting and forecasting precision, ensuring stakeholders can act with confidence
  • Enables analysts to devote more attention to high-value tasks, such as interpreting trends and strategic planning.

3. Supply Chain Automation Agent
Empowering Business Users with AI-driven Fulfillment

Beyond our current solutions, our team is actively developing the Supply Chain Automation Agent. This tool is designed to allow business users to efficiently fulfill trade obligations and maintain inventory balance by streamlining activities such as nominations and ticket postings—directly empowering users with advanced automation.

4. Strategic Partnerships for Next-Generation AI Solutions

To accelerate downstream process automation and streamline field logistics, our team is partnering with AWS to develop multi-agents’ system. These solutions will help optimize both downstream and upstream supply chain operations increasing operational efficiency and reducing costs.

Additionally, in collaboration with Accenture and SAP, we are refining our methodology to ensure that customers are not only leveraging existing AI use cases but also engaging with us to identify new areas for value creation. This approach guarantees that our solutions remain closely aligned with the evolving needs of our client base, fostering continuous improvement and increased efficiency.

Looking Ahead

Our team is committed to delivering impactful AI-driven solutions while cultivating strategic partnerships that expand our ability to solve emerging industry challenges. We look forward to an exciting year ahead as we continue to innovate and deliver to our customers.

For any questions, please reach out to Sumit Shah (sumit.shah@sap.com) or Kelly Boyer (kelly.boyer@sap.com)

If you are curious to find out more and experience some of the mentioned advancements live, please save the date for our SAP for Energy and Utilities Espresso Session on AI updates for oil, gas, and energy, taking place on October 15th at 4:00 PM CET.

entry.title: Clean Core Strategy, a practical approach to get a cleaner on-premise system
entry.content:
Introduction

You may have heard about the term "Clean Core". This blog will not explain what Clean Core means. I've spend lot of time to get familiar with Clean Core and found many great resources and blogs explaining almost all aspects. I don't want to repeat them here.

This blog series instead focuses on what we learned about Clean Core, what our Clean Core strategy looks like and how we try to get back control about our custom developments.

You may need to get the attention of the Board of Management as well as of your team mates. They may ask for reasons why they should spend time and money in Clean Core. This blog series will try to address this as well by providing arguments

If you're in the same situation than we are, I hope this blog series assists you to define your own strategy and tasks.

Today we will focus on why Clean Core is important for us (and you)

Background

tl;dr; if you're just interested in how we handle Clean Core, skip this section

The company I'm working for uses SAP since 1996. During the past 30 years (almost), a legion of internal and external software developers with different skill levels and professions developed almost everything to meet the requirements of our users. Each developer brought his personal background. Some of them started their career back in the 1970's to 1990's with good knowledge about mainframe and midrange systems (do you remember IBM AS/400 systems? If so you know what I mean). Others joined in 2020 and later bringing good knowledge about object oriented software design and knowledge about web technologies.

With the growth of the company, new processes have been introduced, others has been changed and some are not in use anymore. SAP also evolved  over this period and brought us new technologies, products and paradigm in ABAP development. Different skill levels and interests, available technologies, lack of time and documentation multiplied with 3 decades of software development leads to a ton of custom code, a mess inside the code and an incredible high amount of technical debts.

Two years ago, we migrated our ECC system to S/4 HANA. Due to lack of time and budget (again), we've chosen some brown-field approach. We were able to get rid of many development objects but had to keep most of them.

Today we're running S/4 HANA 2023 FP1 on-premise. We use latest SAP technology with added dust of 30 years on top.

Take Away: Innovate and renovate more than 30 years of software development is not a sprint race. It's at least a marathon of several months up to few years with good chance to never reach the finish line. But at least each single step helps you to improve your systems

Clean Core Dimensions

I said I don't want to explain the term Clean Core but it feels like I need to give you a short intro anyway.

Core describes the main aspects of SAP, which can be thought as dimensions and components around

  • E2E processes
  • Data (also customizing)
  • Integration (like 3rd party tool integration)
  • Operations (maintenance activities, release management, jobs etc.)
  • Extensibility (any kind of added custom function)

Clean means that for each of the previously mentioned aspects, the necessary approach is taken for it to be:

  • up-to-date
  • cloud compliant
  • optimized and perfected

depending on the aspect in question.​

Clean core is both a concept and an approach to achieve a modern, flexible, and cloud-compliant SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Clean core is achieved by integration and extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud in such a way that it is cloud-compliant, with optimal master data quality and perfected business process governance. With a clean core, customers experience better maintainability, along with lower total cost of ownership (TCO) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.​1)

1) https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/practicing-clean-core-extensibility-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud/introducing-the-clean-core-approach_fcb6c662-7041-4c99-88bd-345636fae7f3

As I'm a developer, this blog will focus on dimension Extensibility only. This doesn't mean that the company I'm working for ignores the other aspects. You seriously need to take them into account as well. Luckily, those aspects are handled by my SAP Basis and Consultant colleagues.

In short, your system is 100% Clean Core compliant of you can operate it entirely in a public cloud scenario.

At least in our case, we couldn't be more far away from this.

Take Away: define responsibilities for each of these dimensions. You can't handle all of them by your own. Sometimes dimensions and responsibilities are not 100% clear.

For example, a developer will not only be responsible for extensibility but also for integration. A consultant will be responsible for E2E processes but those might need an integration to 3rd party tools as well. Responsibility for integration dimension gets shared between Consultant and Developer.

What's the issue if we're not Clean Core compliant?

Even if we don't plan to move your systems into public cloud, Clean Core is important for us as well

we will upgrade our system at least once a year (we did this only every x years in past)

Each upgrade leads to high effort for reimplementation and testing in both, IT and business

we need to enable ourself to use latest technology to bring down implementation effort and speed up development

Today we almost use no BTP product. Products like AI agents (Joule) will not produce valid results in a highly customized (modified) environment. Other tools like Integration Suites will not support outdated technologies

we have lots of undocumented processes and extensions

Since we started with S/4, many old guys have been retired leading to accumulated brain drop in IT up to 90 years of working experience, more to come in near future.
Due to high amount of custom code and modifications, we encounter high training effort for new colleagues in IT and business. It also leads to high cost for external consultants analyzing our technical debts

we run different implementations for the same processes

We have subsidiaries and production plants all over the world. They're almost the same but each of them brings country specific stuff. In past, code has been duplicated for them. Sometimes we developed a solution not being aware that the dedicated requirement already has been solved for someone else.

we should be prepared for a future move

Even if there is no plan to move to cloud now, who guarantees that we will not do in future?

Take Away: define your own issue list. Think about what will happen, if you don't try to clean up your core.

Extensibility

As developer, I'm mainly responsible for Extensibility. SAP defines an extension like this

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/practicing-clean-core-extensibility-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud/evaluating-the-need-for-extensions_aaae6788-b141-45d3-9d3b-3ead49dba796

We as SAP customer need a dedicated function which is not provided by SAP in standard. Maybe a solution is provided by SAP but lacks in for us important aspects. Welcome to the white area where we develop our solutions.

An extension can be:

  • A custom ABAP report
  • A custom function module
  • Z-Fields and appends to tables
  • User-Exit and BAdI implementations
  • Forms
  • Modification of SAP standard objects

Literally any kind of custom development artifact is an extension.

In past, we used almost any kind of extension type. We developed custom reports, function modules, database objects etc, according to our needs. We made use of 3-layer extensibility supported by SAP (table appends, user exits, dynpro exits). We also used modifications, implicit enhancements and we even copying SAP objects and changed them according to our needs.

Duplicating and modifying SAP objects is a bad idea and is one of the main technical debt. These are old news, we're aware of this since ever. There was a good reason for SAP to introduce SSCR keys to track modifications in your system.

Some main drawbacks  are:

  • High effort for reimplementation and testing during upgrade
  • Often undocumented (at least in our case)
  • Lost of knowledge (retirement)

But we did it anyway because of:

  • High workload and pressure to fulfil our customer needs
  • No alternatives provided by SAP but a business critical need
  • We only upgraded our system every x years
  • Some modifications exists since more than 20 years. No one expected they last so long

What has changed?

These were the main drawbacks and risks we discovered during our first S/4 upgrades

  • SAP removes deprecated user-exists we still use. Even if a dedicated user-exit was marked as deprecated and superseded by BAdI, you could use it anyway as it still was executed. SAP didn't remove obsolete stuff in past (remember transaction MB1A? It was still there for years being deprecated). This has been changed and we came across a situation where an user-exit is still there by definition (meaning EXIT_... FM still exists) but was not executed anymore (https://me.sap.com/notes/3414378)
  • SAP also removes other deprecated, non-released function modules you might use
  • In case of modifications, lot of code has been changed around our modified parts which leads to high effort to reimplement it
  • Sometimes, a modification was easy to reimplement, as source code was the same as before. But this code was not executed anymore as the entire source code of a given transaction has been replaced
  • New technologies can't be used with ease. Do you think AI agent Joule will be able to produce valid results in a highly customized environment? It has been trained by SAP with their own LLM model. But it can't be aware of any modification you made.
  • System will become unmaintainable in future

Conclusion

I hope in this first blog I was able to highlight the importance of Clean Core in general. In the next blogs I will explain our Clean Core strategy in more detail.

I want to finish this blog with a cite from SAP community

„A clean core is not so much a core without custom ABAP, but it is a core with well designed and clearly interfaced and carefully encapsulated custom code.

This code is then far easier to deal with during upgrade situations, and you have more flexibility in terms of future redesigns.“

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-members/occ-abap-cleaners-or-how-to-tidy-up-the-core/ba-p/13557895

entry.title: Clean Core Strategy, a practical approach to get a cleaner on-premise system Part 2
entry.content:
Introduction

In this second blog about Clean Core I want to show you our Clean Core strategy. If you don't know what Clean Core means or if you're interested in where we came from please refer to the first blog of this series.

Background

End of last year, I came to the conclusion that we need to clean up our core by reducing our technical debts. Also we need to ensure to keep it clean and to avoid any new development, which is not Clean Core compliant (as often as possible)

In sum, we need some strategy and guideline. I spent several months in reading about Clean Core and found many, many resources which explains the term, theoretically. Everything makes sense but it was hard to find some practical approach.

I want to share our approach with you hoping to give some impressions to enable you to create your own vision and strategy. I'm also highly interested in your meanings and ideas which might help us to improve our own strategy.

Clean Core Strategy

Measure and Scoping

Before we start to clean up, we need to get a clear picture of the mess. You need to be aware of any custom code object.

  • Get an overview of all modified objects
  • Get a list of all user-exits, BAdIs etc. you implemented
  • Which custom reports are available and are they still in use?
  • Same is true for print forms (SAPScript, SmartForms)
  • Which objects you're responsible for and which will not be part of your activities? For example, we use some abapgit repositories (Excel integration, MS Graph), which might violate Clean Core principles. If you still need them, will it be your task to fix this?

To measure this, we introduced a new KPI for us, the Clean Core Index. The Clean Core Index measures how clean our core is. The lower the value, the better. A Clean Core Index of 0 means, we're 100% Clean Core compliant.

The Clean Core Index is a collection of different measurements, like amount of modifications, reports, forms and others. I'm a developer and I'm lazy, meaning I don't want to do this in Excel manually. Instead, we developed a collection of CDS views to measure and track our progress.

There will be a separate blog about what we measure and how we do that.

We also use SAP standard technologies for our Custom Code Lifecycle Management, like SCMON and Usage and Procedure Logging (UPL). Also we use Custom Code Migration App as well as CCLM of Solution Manager. There is no 100% fit solution available for us. Each solution has its own limitations and drawbacks, but we try to take as much of each solution as possible.

Create awareness in Business and Management

Explain the importance of Clean Core to your Board of Management as well as to your customers in business departments. At the beginning, time you spend in Clean Core activities will not create measurable benefits for your company. Your BoM will need to know, why you have to spend your time in Clean Core activities without creating business value.

Same is true for your customers. They're familiar with their good old processes and custom transaction. They might have used those since more than 10 years and they're afraid in learning new things.

Be prepared for these hurdles. Create some training material to explain what Clean Core means, why it is important and engage your colleagues to participate

Here some arguments from the first blog, which helps especially with the BoM:

  • reduce cost for system maintenance because of reduced time
  • reduced training effort for new joiners. Business colleagues with SAP skills will be more valuable in a system with no or few modifications
  • reduced costs when acting with external partners
  • Speed up your development by using SAP standard whenever possible

Development Guidelines and Governances

Hopefully, you already defined a development guideline which describes the rules of how you develop in SAP. This guideline might be outdated as it mostly describes how you did in past in ECC system. At least our guideline didn't cover S/4 development objects and paradigm, like rules for CDS Views, RESTful ABAP, when to use which technology and so on.

Also create a strong governance and processes to ensure informed decisions. In past, developers modified the system without any approval. Often it was easier and faster for them to modify instead of looking for alternatives. This leads to thousands (yes, I mean more than 1000) modifications in our system, often without any documentation.
To avoid this, each modification must now be approved by Head of IT first.

Quality Gates

Even if the entire team agreed on rules and guidelines, they're human beings. Meaning they will fail to follow the principles in all cases and they will become lazy. To ensure good code quality and guideline, define some quality gates. These gates must be passed successfully before deploying into productive environments.

  1. First of all, we defined our own ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) check variant. It is based on S/4 HANA Readiness check plus some additions.
  2. Install ATC checks for ABAP code-PAL. We don't use all of them but some are pretty handy.
  3. We activated automated ATC checks when releasing a transport request. Now it is mandatory to pass ATC successfully.
  4. We implemented BAdI for transport request creation to prevent developers from creating or releasing a TR of type Repair.
  5. We developed our own ATC checks
    1. There is a ATC check for ABAPDoc comments in classes available in standard. It creates a warning by default, if ABAPDoc is missing. We could change this severity to error but this will lead to the need to adding ABAPDoc to all existing classes. To increase acceptance of developers, we build our own ATC check for ABAPDoc. It will create an error only if a class has been created after a certain date. For each newly created class, ABAPDoc becomes mandatory but changing a class created 10 years ago, there is (actually) no need to add ABAPDoc as well.
    2. To ensure proper documentation of modified objects (in rare case there is no alternative and it has been approved), there is a custom ATC check which look up for documentation to ensure it is available. A modification without documentation will not be moved to productive environment by this
  6. Other ATC check ideas not finalized so far
    1. Ensures a Knowledge Transfer Document (KTD) has been created for each object possible (CDS View, RAP API)
    2. Ensures documentation of custom Fiori App is available in our custom Fiori App Reference library (yes, we introduced our own)
    3. Ensures documentation of CDS Views, RAP APIs, Classes and others is available in our custom api repository (again yes, we introduced our own like api.sap.com)

Engage

Define a learning journey for each member of your team, individually. Ensure to get all of them familiar with S/4 development and your principles. We introduced our own communication channel in MS Teams, which can be taken like a community. All team members are encouraged to post about their latest learning and share their knowledge

Today we almost use none of the product available in SAP BTP, like SAP Build Apps, ABAP Cloud platform, Integration suite, Translation Hub, you name it.

To get familiar with the products available and to find use-cases for us, each team member investigates in one product analyzing how to use it and which benefit it brings for our company. We do this not only to get familiar with these products but also get the colleagues out of their comfort zone and to broaden their scope.

Other dimension

As explained in first blog of this series, Clean Core is not only code but also other dimensions. We simply started with development as we found this will add the most benefit for us. Based on our learnings and fails, other teams started to create their own Clean Core strategy by, again

  • Measuring and defining the scope
  • Define their Clean Core Index
  • Define Quality gates
  • Engage the colleagues

Define targets

You will not be able to renovate 30 years of legacy code within weeks. Clean Core is a journey of several months or few years. Therefore, it is crucial to define targets and steps based on your vision. What do you want to achieve in 6 months? What do you want to achieve after 12 months?

Define realistic targets and define also how to measure your progress. Share your results on a regular basis (we do it on a quarterly basis) with your entire IT team as well as your management and organization

Spoiler alert: the targets were too ambitious.

Short term targets (6 months)

  • Prevent modifications
  • Activate mandatory ATC checks during release of transport request
  • Use Eclipse with ADT only (some still stick to SE80 or even SE38)
  • Use ABAPCleaner in Eclipse
  • Train development team in RESTful ABAP and Fiori Elements
  • Train development team in Key-User Extensibility framework
  • Explore SAP BTP solutions
  • And most important for me, bring Clean Core Index down to a defined value (<15.000 in our case)

Mid-term targets (12 months)

  • ABAP code-PAL as mandatory ATC check
  • Alter ABAP language version to ABAP Cloud for any object possible
  • Stop and prevent developing of custom reports
  • Introduce new communication channels for knowledge transfer
  • Analysis of other dimensions by Consultants
  • Explore even more SAP BTP solutions
  • Refine development guideline by adding use cases and design patterns
  • Resolve all ATC errors (S/4 HANA Readiness check)

Long-term targets (18 months)

  • Evaluate any tier-3 enhancement (classical ABAP) for relevance, alternatives, available documentation and business reason.
  • Migration of all user-exits into BAdI
  • Migration of all SAPScript and SmartForms to Adobe Forms

Development Artifacts and their Clean Core Compliance

After talking so long about vision and strategy, you as a developer still ask, which development artifact is Clean Core compliant and which alternatives are available.

To my understanding, the following table shows development artifacts which are not Clean Core compliant and which technology should be used as alternative

Development artifact not compliant

Compliant alternatives

Modifications

None

User-Exits

Released BAdIs

Duplicates of SAP objects

None

Implicit enhancements

None

Method overriding of SAP standard classes

None

Business Transaction Events (BTE)

Business Object Events, RAP Events

SAPScript and SmartForms

Adobe Forms

Queries (SQ01/SQ02, Quick views)

Analytical CDS views, consumed by analytical Fiori apps or Excel

Z-Reports and custom function modules

RAP API consumed by Fiori or SAP Build apps

Batch-Input in Z-reports

SAP standard API and Business Objects (api.sap.com)

You may wonder about custom reports. They're not Clean Core compliant as, to my best knowledge, you can't develop a custom ABAP report in public cloud. There is also no SAP GUI available. As an alternative, you need to develop Fiori or SAPUI5 apps. SAP Build apps might be also a good alternative.

Sounds good so far? There is one drawback. If you're running on-premise, you define your jobs in SM36/SM37. As job step you only can define ABAP Reports. It is not possible to call a class method, for example. Actually this is the onliest valid use-case for developing a custom report for us.

Conclusion

By writing this, we're in month 8 of our Clean Core journey. We achieved almost all of our short term targets, some were delayed but all were feasible. But we discovered that some of the mid-term and long-term targets might not be feasible at all.

ABAP Code-PAL and ABAP language version ensures to only use officially released objects. I once ran an ATC job with ABAP code-PAL variant. This leads to more than 2.4 million ATC errors as we're using almost no released objects. Or at least, SAP only released few objects compared to what have been used during the past 30 years.

Same is true for ABAP language version. If you change the version of a class, you might need to handle hundreds of errors telling you're using a non-released object. But often there is no alternative available. I can't imagine how much effort is needed to define all the missing but common data elements by your own for public cloud scenario.

We wanted to stop development of custom reports but as already said, sometimes there is no alternative, like for background jobs

We planned to replace all User-Exits by corresponding BAdI. Surprisingly, sometimes it is not possible as no BAdI has been provided so far. We will replace as many user-exits as possible but we can't get rid of all of them.

Migration of forms from SAPScript to Adobe Forms seems also to be a challenging task. Some forms (i.e., purchase orders) are complex and available templates doesn't meet our requirements. I noticed that most of my colleagues are not familiar with developing forms in general. This needs to be addressed in their personal learning journey first. Also it is not easy to identify, if a certain form is still in use or not. We found a solution for SAPScript and SmartForms, more in one of the next blogs.

Evaluating SAP BTP is also not that easy for us. We can make use of trial accounts but not all products are available or only with limited capabilities. For example, we tried to use Translation Hub to translate our existing ABAP texts (text literals, selection screens etc.) into foreign languages. This is possible in general but not in a trial account. The company I'm working for gets owned by an even larger company and we get our licenses by their company agreement with SAP. Often it is not easy to get a clear picture of what has been licensed, what we're allowed to use and what they will charge to us.

Beside these hurdles, we made great progress in reducing our Clean Core Index. The total amount of modifications and reports was reduced dramatically and all ATC findings have been solved so far. Due to our regular announcements about our progress, we get even more support from our business colleagues and management. Both helps us to improve even further.

In the next blog of this series will explain how we define and measure our Clean Core Index

entry.title: Clean Core Index
entry.content:
Introduction

As mentioned in the last blog of this series, we defined our own Clean Core Index. Clean Core Index is a KPI to measure our Clean Core compliance. A Clean Core Index of 0 means, our system is 100% Clean Core compliant and can be run in a public cloud scenario.

The Clean Core Index is one of the most important aspect in our Clean Core strategy. For details about our strategy, please refer to the previous blog entry of this series.

Please note, the Clean Core Index explained here is our company-specific definition. There is no official definition available (at least I'm not aware of). Our Clean Core Index definition definitely doesn't cover all aspects and even if the index will be 0, our system we will not be able to run in a public cloud for sure.

Nonetheless, it helps us to get a better understanding of how clean our core is as well as were we can improve.

Last but not least, managers typically have limited knowledge and understanding about technology and software development. The might not be able to follow when you're talking about importance of Clean Core Strategy and your progress. But they love figures and you will get their attention, if you provide figures to them.

Clean Core Index, definition

First we define all object types, which are relevant for us. Then we added a severity (factor) to each object type together with a reason for the severity.

Ours looks like this

Type

Severity

Reason

Reports

1

High effort needed for redesign, no cost savings

Function Modules

1

High effort needed for redesign, no cost savings

SAPScript + Smartforms

2

Obsolete since 20 years, high effort for redesign, low risk but seriously outdated. Should be replaced each time one asks for a change on such a form

ATC Errors (S/4 readiness check)

5

Easy to handle, doesn‘t influence upgrade processes. Exists because we became lazy

User Exits without released BAdI as successor

5

No alternative available, should be verified after each upgrade 1)

User Exits with released BAdI as successor

8

Low effort for redesign, high risk during upgrade 1)

Modifications

10

High risk, high effort during upgrade

Impl. Enhancements

10

High risk, high effort during upgrade

We now determine the count per object type and multiply this with the corresponding severity. Voila, your Clean Core Index has been calculated.

Some notes about ATC errors. During our conversion from ECC to S/4, we had to deal with all ATC errors resulting from S/4 HANA Readiness check. We solved all Priority 1 findings. When we started with our Clean Core Strategy, we noticed that again there were ATC prio 1 findings. Didn't we solve all of them during our migration? There are two reasons

  • S/4 readiness check evolves also. We use latest available, which now includes checks which were not available during our migration
  • We became lazy. We once agreed to run ATC for any kind of development but people stopped to do this. They developed like they did before resulting in new ATC findings.

Some notes about User-Exits. Most User-Exits have been replaced by a BAdI but some still have not been replaced. There is no way to distinguish between those. Instead, each User-Exit needs to be checked manually. I wasn't aware of this at the beginning and therefore defined different severities. Now, each User-Exit gets handled with severity of 8.

Clean Core Index, how to measure

To measure the Clean Core Index, several CDS Views have been developed. You find everything in this git repository.

https://github.com/sap-weberpatrick/Clean-Core-Index

UPL SAPScript

Special note about usage statistics for SAPScript and SmartForms. It is not that straight forward to identify, if a form is in use or not. For this, I developed my own report which runs periodically. Results are stored in a dedicated Z-Table. You find this report and class as well inside of the git repository.

Clean Core Index, initial figures

Conclusion

By measuring the index regularly, like once per week, we can track our progress. We're also able to track progress by module (MM, PP, SD,…) as well as by type (modification, ATC, reports).

entry.title: Re: Seamless Transition from SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
The SAP Enterprise Support Academy offers two Expert Guided Implementation (EGI) sessions to support the move to Cloud ALM:

  • All You Need to Know About SAP Cloud ALM - this EGI presents the benefits and capabilities of SAP Cloud ALM.  And SAP expert works with participants on the initial setup and connectivity then combines knowledge transfer on the Implementation, Operations and Service topics to allowing you to leverage the full potential of SAP Cloud ALM.
  • Selective Data Transfer from Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM helps you plan and execute the migration of data from SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM using the Selective Data Transfer (SDT) methodology, process and tool. You will learn how to analyze your SAP Solution Manager 7.2 system with the Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM and determine if the Selective Data Transfer is relevant or not. 

PLEASE NOTE - In order to access the registration links above, a one time registration to the SAP Enterprise Support Academy is required.

entry.title: Re: Condition Contract - Delta Accrual
entry.content:
Hi @HendryTj , 

Per default the delta accrual pricing date will be the final settlement date, hence will apply the relevant rate of the Final Settlement date. You can change this logic in Specify Settlement Settings for Condition Contract type under Delta Accrual section: 

Furthermore, you have also the possibility to split the line item and business volume per condition record validity with the following settings: 

I want to provide a quick reminder: even though you selected Separate for Partial Settlement type, it does mean that the partial settlement will be separate however the final settlement will still be cumulative and will capture the complete business volume since day 1 of the contract and recalculate with the latest rate. 

Downside of the above: Multiplying the number of line items. 

Another way to handle purely/strictly separate rates on multi period condition record for a Condition Contract would be to use a Final Settlement for each period within the same contract. 

Downside of the above, if you need to recalculate the amount you will have to use Delta Settlement (e.g. source document reversed after settlement, source document posted after relevant settlement document, change in the rate, change in the business volume selection...). 

Regards, 
Gauthier Victor

entry.title: Re: How to pick and Config highest tax percentage from PO...
entry.content:
Hello @Satz_Prinz 

In standard SAP pricing, there is no automatic feature to dynamically select the highest tax percentage from all PO line items and apply it to condition types such as freight, packing, or insurance. By default, tax determination in MM pricing is based on

  • Condition Records (via FV11 / FV12 or BRF and in Public Cloud)
  • Access Sequences tied to the tax condition types (MWST, JVRD, etc.)
  • Calculation Schema logic in the PO

Options to achieve your requirement:

Custom Condition Base Formula (Routine) in Pricing

    • Create a custom routine (VOFM → Formulas → Condition Base Value) to determine the highest tax % from the current PO and apply it to the relevant freight/insurance condition types.
    • Assign this routine to the Condition Type in the calculation schema.
    • In Public Cloud, this would be done via a BAdI in Business Add-In for Pricing in Purchase Documents (e.g., MM_PUR_S4_PRICING_CUSTOM), since VOFM is not directly available.

Use a Freight/Insurance Condition Dependent on Tax Condition

    • Configure the freight/insurance condition type to reference the tax condition type in its calculation formula.
    • Maintain the key combination in the condition record so that it inherits the percentage from the highest line-item tax code.

Manual Handling (Standard Functionality)

  • If automation is not possible, enter the tax code for freight/insurance lines manually with the highest tax percentage applicable in that PO.

SAP Documentation helpful References.

SAP Help – Define Pricing Procedures for Purchasing

3636847 - Tax item information on Purchase Order Output Forms

3580006 - Purchase Order Price Enhancement in SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition

With kind regards

Chuma
